tasks.title: Epic: Rust Rewrite (non-legacy parity, final switch)
tasks.body:
Goal:
- Rewrite Forge to Rust in-repo.
- Preserve parity for all non-legacy behavior.
- Execute single final switch, with continuous parity checks before cutover.

In scope:
- Loops runtime + smart-stop + queue semantics.
- Profiles/pools/config/runtime ownership behavior.
- forge CLI non-legacy commands.
- forged daemon + forge-agent-runner protocols.
- fmail core/CLI/TUI.
- Loop TUI + fmail TUI on FrankenTUI.

Out of scope:
- Legacy interactive command setup and disabled legacy paths.

Definition of done:
- Rust binaries pass parity matrix + CI gates.
- Full unit test coverage policy enforced for Rust crates.
- Single final switch completed with rollback plan validated.

tasks.title: Baseline characterization harness (Go oracle)
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Build characterization harness against current Go implementation.
- Snapshot CLI behavior and high-value runtime scenarios.

Deliverables:
- Golden snapshots: help text, flags, exit-code expectations.
- Scenario fixtures: loops/profiles/pools/msg/queue/stop/resume/smart-stop.
- fmail fixtures: send/inbox/read/ack/topics/watch semantics.

Acceptance:
- Baseline snapshots reproducible in CI.
- Drift detection fails PR when behavior changes unexpectedly.
- Harness can compare Go vs Rust outputs with normalizers.

Tests:
- Harness self-tests.
- Smoke test for each fixture set.

- Rollback safety validated for supported downs.

Tests:
- Migration up/down tests.
- Schema introspection tests.
- Corrupt-state resilience tests.

tasks.title: Epic: Forge TUI 1% UX Excellence
tasks.body: Unify and ship a top-percentile Forge TUI experience. Scope: navigation speed, observability depth, matrix usability, performance, accessibility, and incident replay.

tasks.title: TUI: Performance mode and incremental rendering
tasks.body: Optimize refresh cadence and rendering for high loop counts; avoid full redraw hot paths.

tasks.title: fmail TUI perf: incremental search index + TTL tuning
tasks.body:

- Revisit search index lifecycle and TTL behavior.
- Avoid broad index rebuild on short intervals.

Acceptance:

Tests:

tasks.title: fmail TUI perf: subscribe polling + scan dedupe
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Optimize FileProvider Subscribe() polling:
  - avoid repeated full directory walks per tick.
  - coalesce bursts and dedupe repeated scans.
  - support adaptive/backoff polling intervals.
- Tune defaults from current aggressive values to balanced latency/cpu.
- Expose poll/cache knobs in fmail TUI config.

Acceptance:
- Lower idle CPU during TUI run with no new messages.
- New message detection remains timely.

Tests:
- Unit tests for watcher backoff/coalescing behavior.
- Integration-style test for delivery order + no duplicates.

tasks.title: fmail TUI perf: timeline windowing + lazy paging
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Redesign timeline data flow for bounded window reads.
- Add lazy paging/chunking (initial window + fetch more on demand).
- Prevent full all-topics/all-dm aggregation on each refresh.

Acceptance:
- Timeline initial load bounded and fast.
- Scroll/navigation does not stall when history grows.

Tests:
- Unit tests for window bounds/paging logic.
- Integration test for incremental timeline growth.

tasks.title: fmail TUI UX: visual/readability polish pass
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Improve first-pass visual quality with focus on readability and hierarchy in key views.
- Ensure high-value flows (dashboard -> topics -> thread -> search) are coherent and stable.
- Fix obvious rendering/interaction inconsistencies discovered during manual UX pass.

Acceptance:

- No regressions in keyboard navigation or read markers.

Tests:
- Update/extend view tests where behavior changes.
- Manual verification checklist in docs.

tasks.title: fmail TUI perf: harness + budgets + regression guardrails
tasks.body:

- Add reproducible perf harness for fmail TUI provider/view hot paths.

Acceptance:

tasks.title: Epic: fmail TUI v2 perf + UX stabilization
tasks.body:
Goal: first pass stabilization of fmail TUI UX + performance.

User issue:
- TUI feels rough visually.
- Loading full message state feels too slow.

Scope:
- Data-provider hot paths (topics/dm/search/subscribe).
- View reload strategy (timeline/topics/dashboard/stats/graph).
- Faster initial load and interaction responsiveness.
- Guardrails: measurable budgets, regression tests, perf harness.

Success:
- Cold start and core view navigation feel immediate on medium stores.
- No repeated full-store scans on short timer ticks.
- Team has benchmark + smoke commands to catch regressions.

tasks.title: fmail TUI perf: incremental topic/DM metadata index
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Rework FileProvider metadata path to avoid full message loads on each Topics/DMConversations call.
- Add incremental metadata cache/index keyed by topic + dm peer (message count, last activity, participants, last id).
- Invalidate incrementally from Subscribe/new-file detection rather than broad rescans.
- Add config surface for cache TTL defaults tuned for file store.

Acceptance:
- Topics()/DMConversations() avoid loading all message bodies on steady-state calls.
- Repeated metadata calls are near-constant time after warmup.

Tests:
- Unit tests for cache correctness and invalidation.
- Regression test for repeated Topics()/DMConversations() call count/behavior.

tasks.title: fmail TUI perf: topics/dashboard incremental refresh
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Refactor topics/dashboard refresh so message-event tick does not trigger broad reload every cycle.
- Replace full Messages()/DMs() reload loops with incremental counters/state updates.
- Unread and hot-topic counts computed from cached metadata + read markers.

Acceptance:
- topics/dashboard view update cost scales with delta, not total store size.
- No repeated full-topic scan on every timer tick.

Tests:
- Regression tests for unread/hot counts correctness.
- Tests for reload throttling/debouncing behavior.

tasks.title: M10.6: Harness capability matrix + mode guardrails
tasks.body:
Scope:

  - supports_interactive_subagent
  - supports_reliable_idle_detection
  - supports_approval_signal
  - default_command_mode (interactive vs one-shot)
- Add guardrails:
  - reject continuous-subagent requests for one-shot command modes.
  - suggest fix (e.g., use interactive codex command, not codex exec).
- Expose capability info in subagent show/doctor output.

Acceptance:
- User cannot accidentally create "continuous" subagent on one-shot mode without explicit override.
- Messages clearly explain mismatch.

Tests:
- Unit tests for capability lookup and guards.

tasks.title: M10.1: Subagent model + lifecycle state machine
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Define canonical Subagent model: id, parent_subagent_id/parent_agent_id, workspace/repo, node, harness, mode, state, created_at, last_activity_at, ttl, labels/tags.
- Define state machine: starting -> idle/working/awaiting_approval -> idle ... -> stopped/error/expired.
- Define transitions + invariants (e.g. send only when subagent exists; revive only from stopped/error/expired).
- Define mapping between forged AgentState and new SubagentState.
- Define contract for "continuous" vs "one-shot" subagents.

Deliverables:
- Design doc in docs/design/subagent-lifecycle.md
- State diagram + transition table.
- Error taxonomy (not_found, not_interactive, dead_subagent, transport_unavailable, timeout_waiting_idle, policy_denied).

Acceptance:
- All subagent commands reference same state definitions.
- No ambiguous transitions.
- Edge cases documented: daemon restart, pane missing, process exit, approval wait.

Tests:
- Unit tests for transition validator.

tasks.title: M10: Persistent subagents (non-loop delegation)
tasks.body:
Goal:
- Add first-class persistent subagents for non-loop workflows.
- Parent agent can spawn child, send one-off work, then continue chatting with same child on demand.
- Keep subagents alive between tasks; support revive/resume when possible.

Problem:
- Current loop-first UX good for continuous repo loops, poor fit for ad-hoc delegated one-off + re-engage workflow.
- Existing forged RPC has spawn/send primitives, but no stable end-user subagent primitive in forge CLI.

Scope:
- New subagent lifecycle primitive (spawn/send/wait/list/interrupt/kill/revive).
- Explicit harness capability handling (interactive vs one-shot modes).
- Parent-focused delegation helper command for low-friction use.
- Persistence, observability, safety policies, docs.

Out of scope:
- Replacing loop runtime.
- Full autonomous team routing system (covered by M7+).

Success metrics:
- Parent can re-use same child subagent across multiple delegated tasks in one day.
- Median command count for delegated task <= 3 commands.
- Failed delegation due to dead/non-interactive subagent reduced via capability checks and revive path.

Acceptance:
- CLI subagent flow works end-to-end locally and with forged daemon.
- Harness mismatch errors are explicit/actionable.
- Subagent state is inspectable and auditable.

tasks.title: M10.3: Subagent service on top of forged transport
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Implement forged-backed Subagent service APIs using existing SpawnAgent/SendInput/List/Get/Kill primitives.
- Add abstraction so subagent ops can run local or daemon-backed consistently.
- Implement operations: SpawnSubagent, SendMessage, WaitState, InterruptSubagent, KillSubagent, ListSubagents, GetSubagent.
- Store each operation in subagent_events.
- Normalize transport errors.

Acceptance:
- Service can manage multiple concurrent subagents.
- WaitState works for idle/working/approval/stopped with timeout.
- Failures emit structured events and retain debug context.

Tests:
- Unit tests with mocked forged client.
- Integration test with local forged daemon for spawn/send/wait/kill.

tasks.title: M10.12: End-to-end and regression test matrix
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Build comprehensive test matrix:
  - spawn/send/wait/interrupt/kill/revive
  - capability mismatch paths
  - daemon unavailable fallback errors
  - multi-subagent concurrency
- Add regression tests for known pitfalls:
  - one-shot harness used as continuous subagent
  - stale pane ID after restart

Acceptance:
- CI includes subagent flow tests with stable fixtures.
- Failures isolate root cause quickly.

tasks.title: M10.5: Parent-oriented forge subagent run helper
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Add high-level parent-helper command:
  - forge subagent run "task" [--subagent <id>] [--type codex] [--wait idle] [--revive]
- Behavior:
  - if subagent exists: reuse.
  - else spawn with requested/default profile.
  - send task.
  - optionally wait for idle/completion marker.
  - return summary payload for parent automation.
- Include ergonomic flags for label/tag/task-id correlation.

Acceptance:
- One command handles common delegation loop.
- Re-run with same --subagent continues prior callee context.
- Output includes subagent_id + observed state + quick tail.

Tests:
- Integration tests for create/reuse/revive paths.

tasks.title: M10.4: CLI surface for forge subagent commands
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Add CLI group: forge subagent.
- Subcommands:
  - forge subagent spawn
  - forge subagent send
  - forge subagent wait
  - forge subagent ps
  - forge subagent show
  - forge subagent interrupt
  - forge subagent kill
  - forge subagent revive
- Add JSON output contracts for automation.
- Add context-aware defaults (workspace, last subagent, parent marker) without hidden magic.

Acceptance:
- Non-interactive automation works with --json.
- Human UX concise and predictable.
- Errors provide next-step hints.

Tests:
- CLI tests for parse/validation.
- Golden tests for JSON output envelopes.

tasks.title: M10.2: Subagent persistence (DB schema + repos)
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Add DB schema for persistent subagents + subagent events/messages.
- Suggested tables:
  - subagents
  - subagent_messages (outbound/inbound metadata)
  - subagent_events (state transitions, control actions)
- Add repositories for CRUD/list/filter and append-only event writes.
- Add indexes for hot paths: by state, by parent, by updated_at, by workspace.
- Add migration rollback safety.

Acceptance:
- Subagent survives process restart.
- Listing by workspace/parent/state efficient.
- Event history queryable for audit/explain.

Tests:
- Migration tests up/down.
- Repository tests for create/get/list/filter/pagination.

tasks.title: M10.8: Subagent revive/resume workflow
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Implement revive workflow:
  - detect dead subagent (pane/process missing).
  - respawn compatible subagent.
  - inject revive preamble containing compact context (last task, summary, pending objective).
- Add revive policy flags:
  - never
  - ask
  - auto
- Ensure revive preserves parent linkage and audit trail.

Acceptance:
- Revive success path transparent to caller.
- Revive failure returns actionable remediation.

Tests:
- Integration tests for dead-subagent detection + respawn.

tasks.title: M10.14: Subagent observability + explain support
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Add observability:
  - counters: subagents_spawned, subagents_revived, sends, interrupts, kill, wait_timeout
  - gauges: active_subagents, idle_subagents
  - latency: send_to_idle_duration
- Add explain integration for subagent IDs.

Acceptance:
- Operators can answer: what subagents exist, which are stale, where failures happen.
- Metrics emitted for both success and failure paths.

Tests:
- Unit tests for metric emission hooks.

tasks.title: M10.13: Docs and troubleshooting for delegated subagents
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Docs updates:
  - README section for subagent workflows.
  - docs/cli.md subagent commands + examples.
  - docs/quickstart.md delegation recipe.
  - docs/troubleshooting.md subagent failure playbook.
- Add explicit harness-mode guidance (interactive vs one-shot).

Acceptance:
- New user can run delegated continuous subagent flow in <10 min.
- Docs include at least 3 real command recipes.

tasks.title: M10.11: Subagent summaries for parent rehydration
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Add transcript summarization helper for parent agents:
  - concise status
  - latest task outcome
  - unresolved blockers
- Store summary snapshots in subagent_events or dedicated summary table.
- Add CLI: forge subagent summary <id>.

Acceptance:
- Parent can quickly rehydrate child context without full log dump.
- Summary generation bounded/performant.

Tests:
- Unit tests for summarizer formatting.

tasks.title: M10.10: Approval/policy inheritance and redaction
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Propagate approval policy + account/profile context from parent to child spawn defaults.
- Add policy checks for risky send/interrupt commands.
- Add redaction rules for sensitive payloads in subagent events.

Acceptance:
- Child runs with expected approval posture.
- Sensitive text not leaked in audit fields.

Tests:
- Unit tests for policy inheritance + redaction.

tasks.title: M10.9: TTL, idle expiry, and subagent GC
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Add lifecycle controls for parked subagents:
  - ttl
  - idle timeout
  - optional max age
- Add GC worker/command to terminate expired subagents safely.
- Emit events before/after eviction.

Acceptance:
- Stale subagents do not accumulate indefinitely.
- Active subagents not evicted prematurely.

Tests:
- Unit tests for TTL evaluator.
- Integration test for GC path.

tasks.title: M10.7: Wait semantics and state synchronization
tasks.body:
Scope:
- Implement robust wait semantics:
  - wait for idle
  - wait for approval-needed
  - wait for stopped/error
  - timeout/cancel support
- Add event-stream + polling fallback strategy.
- Add --until and --timeout controls in CLI.

Acceptance:
- Wait command deterministic; no busy-looping.
- Timeout exits with typed error and last observed state.

Tests:
- Unit tests with simulated state streams.
- Integration tests with delayed transitions.

tasks.title: Epic: fmail TUI  Live Conversation Viewer
tasks.body:
A comprehensive TUI for watching fmail conversations in real-time and reviewing past activity. Built with Bubbletea/Lipgloss, integrating with forged for live streaming and the .fmail/ file store for historical data.

## Goals
- Real-time visibility into all agent-to-agent communication
- Historical replay and search across all messages
- Agent presence and activity monitoring
- Powerful filtering, search, and navigation
- Sequence diagram / timeline views for understanding coordination patterns
- Composing and sending messages directly from the TUI

## Phases
1. Foundation & Core Infrastructure (P0)
2. Core Views  Live Feed, Topics, Threads, Agents (P0-P1)
3. Power Features  Search, Timeline, Replay, Graph (P1-P2)
4. Operational Features  Compose, Bookmarks, Notifications (P2)
5. UX Polish  Keybindings, Layouts, Themes, Status Bar (P2-P3)

## Technical Notes
- Use Bubbletea (charmbracelet) for TUI framework, Lipgloss for styling
- Connect to forged via Unix socket (.fmail/forged.sock) or TCP (127.0.0.1:7463) for real-time
- Fall back to file-based polling (100ms) in standalone mode
- Message format: JSON files in .fmail/topics/<topic>/ and .fmail/dm/<agent>/
- Message IDs are sortable: YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS-NNNN
- Reply chains via reply_to field
- Agent registry in .fmail/agents/<name>.json
- Local TUI state (read markers, bookmarks, annotations) in .fmail/tui-state.json

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Replay Mode (time-travel playback)
tasks.body:
Build a Replay Mode that allows scrubbing through historical message activity at variable speed.

## Layout
```
 REPLAY   10x  15:30:00 / 16:45:00 
                                                          
  (same layout as Live Dashboard or Timeline, but         
   showing historical state at the playback cursor)       
                                                          
  Agents at 15:30:                                        
   architect (active)                                    
   coder-1 (idle since 15:15)                           
                                                          
  Messages arriving:                                      
  15:30:01 architect  task                              
    implement JWT auth...                                 
  ... (messages appear as time advances) ...              
                                                          

       PLAYING                                  
  [=========>-----------] 15:30  16:45        
  Speed: [1x] [5x] [10x] [50x]                          

 Space: play/pause  /: skip  1-4: speed  Home/End: start/end
```

## Deliverables
- Playback scrubber:
  - Horizontal progress bar showing position within the replay time range
  - Time range: auto-detected from first to last message in the store (or user-specified)
  - Current playback position shown as HH:MM:SS above the scrubber
  - Drag/click on scrubber to jump to any point (or use / to step)
  - /: skip forward/back by 1 message
  - Shift+/: skip forward/back by 1 minute
  - Home/End: jump to start/end
- Playback controls:
  - Space: play/pause
  - Speed presets: 1 = real-time (1x), 2 = 5x, 3 = 10x, 4 = 50x
  - Speed shown in the header
  - During playback, messages appear in the feed at accelerated rate
  - Each message "arrives" at its relative timestamp scaled by speed
- Replay view:
  - Default: uses the Live Dashboard layout (agents + feed)
  - Toggle to Timeline layout with `t`
  - Agent presence recalculated at each point in time:
    - An agent is "active" if they sent a message within the last 5 minutes (relative to playback position)
  - Message feed shows only messages up to the current playback position
  - New messages "arrive" with a brief highlight animation (bold for 500ms)
- Replay state:
  - "State at time T" computation:
    - Active agents: filter agent records by activity relative to T
    - Active topics: topics with messages before T
    - Unread counts: as if ReadMarkers were at T
    - Message feed: all messages with timestamp  T
  - Pre-compute a sorted list of all message timestamps for efficient seeking
- Bookmarkable positions:
  - Press `m` to mark the current position (like vim marks)
  - Press `'` + letter to jump to a marked position
  - Marks shown as notches on the scrubber bar
- Export:
  - Press `e` to export the visible time range as a markdown report
  - Report includes: time range, active agents, all messages formatted
  - Written to .fmail/exports/replay-YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS.md

## Technical Notes
- Pre-load all messages sorted by timestamp into memory for the replay session
- Use a timer (tea.Tick) for playback, interval = (real_time_between_messages / speed)
- For gaps >30s between messages at current speed, fast-forward the clock (don't make users wait)
- Replay mode is read-only  no sending messages from this view
- State computation should be efficient: use binary search on sorted timestamps for "messages up to T"
- Memory: for very large message stores (>100K messages), stream from disk instead of pre-loading
- Playback position persisted in TUI state so user can resume replay later

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Conversation Graph (agent interaction network)
tasks.body:
Build a Conversation Graph view showing agent-to-agent communication as a network visualization.

## Layout
```
 Graph  last 4h  156 messages 
                                                          
                                              
              > coder-1  <                     
                    (42)                              
                                            
                15 msgs           8 msgs               
                                 
         architect         reviewer                  
           (67)          (23)                   
           23                     
                                                         
         7 msgs                                          
                                               
          tester                                        
           (12)                                         
                                               
                                                          
  Legend: (N) = total messages sent                       
  Edge = message count between agents                    
   = high volume   = low volume                    

 +/- zoom  // pan  Enter: detail  period: [/]  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Network graph rendering:
  - Each agent is a node (box) with: name (colored) + total message count
  - Edges between agents who have communicated (DMs or shared topics)
  - Edge thickness proportional to message volume:
    - Thin () for 1-5 messages
    - Medium () for 6-20 messages
    - Thick (double ) for 20+ messages
  - Edge labels: message count
  - Directed edges: arrows showing which direction messages flow ()
  - Bidirectional edges: double arrows ()
  - Node size (box width) proportional to total messages sent
  - Layout algorithm: force-directed (simplified for terminal):
    - Most-connected agent in center
    - Agents positioned by connectivity (closer = more messages between them)
    - Avoid overlapping boxes
- Time range:
  - Default: last 4 hours
  - Adjustable with `[` (shrink) and `]` (expand): 1h, 4h, 12h, 24h, 7d, all-time
  - Graph re-renders with updated data for the selected range
  - Show time range and total message count in header
- Interaction:
  - Navigate between nodes with ///
  - Enter on a node  show popup with agent detail (messages sent/received, top topics, top correspondents)
  - Enter on an edge  show messages between those two agents
  - `c`  toggle cluster detection: auto-group agents that form working clusters
    - Clusters drawn as dotted rectangles around agent groups
    - Cluster = agents with >50% of their messages going to other cluster members
- Topic overlay:
  - Press `t` to toggle topic overlay
  - Topics shown as circles instead of boxes
  - Edges go agent  topic  agent, showing which topics connect agents
  - Color-coded by topic

## Technical Notes
- Terminal graph rendering is inherently limited  keep it simple and readable
- Force-directed layout: simplified version
  1. Start with agents in a circle
  2. Iteratively: attract connected nodes, repel all nodes, settle after N iterations
  3. Snap to character grid (each node occupies a rectangular area)
  4. Max 12 agents displayed (combine least-active into an "others" node)
- For rendering: use box-drawing characters () and arrows ()
- Edge routing: simple Manhattan routing (horizontal then vertical) with collision avoidance
- This view is optional/secondary  prioritize it being informative over perfectly laid out
- Re-render only when time range changes or on explicit refresh, not on every message

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Activity Heatmap view
tasks.body:
Build an Activity Heatmap showing agent communication patterns over time, similar to GitHub's contribution graph.

## Layout
```
 Activity Heatmap  last 24h 
                                                          
  Hour:  00  02  04  06  08  10  12  14  16  18  20  22  
           
 archit                   
 coder-1                  
 tester                   
 review                         
 deploy                            
           
                                                          
  Legend:  1-5 msgs   6-15 msgs   16+ msgs           
                                                          

  Summary:                                                
  Peak hour: 14:00-15:00 (47 messages)                   
  Most active: architect (67 msgs)                       
  Busiest topic: task (89 msgs)                          
  Avg response time: 2m 15s                              

 [/] time range  s: sort  t: topic view  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Heatmap grid:
  - Rows: one per agent (sorted by total activity, most active at top)
  - Columns: time buckets (granularity depends on range)
    - 24h view: 1-hour buckets (24 columns)
    - 7d view: 4-hour buckets (42 columns)
    - 30d view: 1-day buckets (30 columns)
  - Cell intensity: block characters with varying density
    - Empty: no messages
    -  (light): 1-5 messages
    -  (medium): 6-15 messages
    -  (dense): 16-30 messages
    -  (full): 31+ messages
  - Color scale: cool (blue/cyan) for low activity  warm (yellow/red) for high
  - Thresholds auto-scaled to the data (percentile-based)
- Time range controls:
  - `[` to shrink, `]` to expand: 4h, 12h, 24h, 7d, 30d
  - / to pan the time window
  - Current range shown in header
- Topic heatmap mode:
  - Press `t` to toggle: rows become topics instead of agents
  - Shows which topics are hot at which times
  - Same color scale and controls
- Summary panel (below heatmap):
  - Peak hour: time bucket with most messages
  - Most active agent: agent with highest message count in range
  - Busiest topic: topic with highest message count in range
  - Average response time: mean time between a message and its first reply (across all threads)
  - Total messages in range
  - Unique agents active in range
- Sort options:
  - `s` cycles: by total activity, by name, by peak time, by recency
- Cell detail:
  - Navigate to a cell with arrow keys
  - Show tooltip: "architect, 14:00-15:00: 23 messages (task: 15, build: 5, DMs: 3)"
  - Enter on a cell  filter Timeline view to that agent + time range

## Technical Notes
- Heatmap data: aggregate message counts into time buckets per agent
- Pre-compute when entering the view (scan all messages in time range)
- Auto-scale thresholds: compute percentiles (25th, 50th, 75th, 95th) of non-zero cell values
- Response time calculation: for each message with reply_to, compute delta between reply and parent
  - Cache this per-thread, only recompute for new messages
- Rendering: each cell is 3 characters wide (to fit in standard terminals)
- For 30d view with many agents, support vertical scrolling
- Agent name column: truncate to 8 chars with "..." for narrow terminals

Scope:

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Stats Dashboard view
tasks.body:
Build a Stats Dashboard showing aggregate communication metrics and analytics.

## Layout
```
 Stats  last 24h 
                                                          
  OVERVIEW                      MESSAGES OVER TIME       
  Total messages: 342              
  Active agents:  6                
  Active topics:  8             06:00     12:00    18:00 
  Avg reply time: 2m 15s                                
  Longest thread: 12 msgs      TOPIC VOLUME             
                                task      89     
  TOP AGENTS (by msgs sent)     build     52        
  1. architect   67    review    43         
  2. coder-1     52      editing   23           
  3. reviewer    43       deploy    12            
  4. tester      23                                  
  5. deployer    12           RESPONSE LATENCY         
                                <30s    45%  
  BUSIEST HOUR                  1-5m   28%        
  14:00-15:00 (47 msgs)        5-30m  18%          
                                >30m   9%             

 [/] time range  r: refresh  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Overview panel:
  - Total message count in time range
  - Unique active agents (agents who sent at least 1 message)
  - Unique active topics
  - Average reply time (mean of reply-to-parent deltas)
  - Median reply time
  - Longest thread (most messages in a single reply chain)
  - Most replied-to message (message with the most direct replies)
- Top agents:
  - Sorted list of agents by messages sent
  - Horizontal bar chart using block characters
  - Show: rank, agent name (colored), count, bar
  - Top 10, or all if fewer
- Messages over time:
  - Line chart / sparkline showing message volume over time
  - X-axis: time, Y-axis: message count per bucket
  - Bucket size depends on time range (same as heatmap)
  - Use braille characters () for high-resolution sparkline
  - Or use block characters () for simpler rendering
- Topic volume:
  - Horizontal bar chart of messages per topic
  - Sorted by volume descending
  - Color-coded bars (topic colors)
- Response latency distribution:
  - Histogram of reply times bucketed into: <30s, 30s-5m, 5m-30m, 30m-2h, >2h
  - Horizontal bar chart with percentage
  - Color-coded: green (<30s), yellow (30s-5m), orange (5m-30m), red (>30m)
- Busiest hour:
  - Single highlighted stat: the hour with most messages
  - "Quietest hour" below it
- Time range controls:
  - Same as heatmap: [/] to adjust, / to pan
  - 4h, 12h, 24h, 7d, 30d, all-time
- Auto-refresh: recompute every 30 seconds when live data is flowing
- Thread depth analysis:
  - Average thread depth (number of messages per thread)
  - Distribution: 1 msg (standalone), 2-3, 4-10, 10+
  - Shown as small bar chart or counts

## Technical Notes
- All stats computed from in-memory message data (same cache as other views)
- Response latency: only count messages where reply_to exists and parent is found
- Sparkline rendering: use a ring buffer of bucket counts, render proportional heights
- Braille sparklines: charmbracelet/bubbles has a sparkline component, or implement with braille unicode block (U+2800-U+28FF)
- For "all-time" range, scan entire .fmail/ store  may be slow, show loading indicator
- Cache computed stats, invalidate on new messages

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Bookmarks and Annotations
tasks.body:
Build bookmarking and annotation features for saving and annotating important messages.

## Layout  Bookmarks Panel
```
 Bookmarks  12 saved 
                                                          
 Filter: _________                                        
                                                          
  "JWT auth decision"  architect in task (15:34)       
   Note: Final decision was single-use refresh tokens     
                                                          
   "Test command"  tester in build (14:20)              
   Note: go test ./auth/... -tags=integration             
                                                          
   "Deploy checklist"  deployer in deploy (12:00)       
   (no note)                                              
                                                          
   "Bug report"  reviewer in @architect (11:30)         
   Note: Race condition in token validation               
                                                          

 Enter: go to message  e: edit note  d: delete  x: export  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Bookmarking:
  - Press `b` on any selected message in any view to bookmark it
  - Quick bookmark: no prompt, just saves with no note
  - `B` (shift+b): bookmark with note  opens a small input for the annotation
  - Bookmarked messages shown with a  indicator in all views
  - Bookmark stored in tui-state.json: {messageID, topic, note, createdAt}
  - Toggle: pressing `b` on an already-bookmarked message removes the bookmark (with confirmation)
- Bookmarks panel (dedicated view):
  - Access via `Ctrl+B` or from the dashboard
  - List all bookmarks sorted by creation date (newest first)
  - Each entry shows: note (if any), sender, topic, timestamp
  - Preview of the message body below the note
  - Filter bar: fuzzy search across notes and message bodies
  - Sort options: by date bookmarked, by message date, by topic, by agent
- Annotations:
  - Annotations are notes attached to specific messages (different from bookmark notes)
  - Press `a` on a selected message to add/edit an annotation
  - Annotations shown as a colored note below the message in Thread View:
    ```
     architect (15:34)
     Single-use refresh tokens...
      Your note: This was the key design decision for the auth system
    ```
  - Annotations are local-only (stored in tui-state.json)
  - Annotation shown in all views where the message appears
- Export:
  - From the bookmarks panel, press `x` to export all bookmarks as markdown
  - Export format:
    ```markdown
    # Bookmarks - Exported 2026-02-09 16:00:00
    
    ## JWT auth decision
    **From:** architect  task | **Time:** 15:34:10
    **Note:** Final decision was single-use refresh tokens
    
    > Single-use. Each refresh mints a new refresh token alongside the access token.
    > The old refresh token is immediately invalidated.
    
    ---
    ```
  - Export a single thread: `X` (shift+x) from Thread View exports the full thread as markdown
  - Output to .fmail/exports/ directory
- Bookmarks in search:
  - `has:bookmark` filter in search to find only bookmarked messages
  - `has:annotation` filter to find annotated messages

## Technical Notes
- Bookmark limit: 500 (prune oldest on save if exceeded, warn user)
- Annotations stored as map[messageID]string in tui-state.json
- Bookmark lookup: keep a set of bookmarked message IDs for O(1) lookup during render
- Export uses the same message rendering as Thread View but in markdown format
- Export directory created automatically if it doesn't exist (.fmail/exports/)

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Search and Filter engine
tasks.body:
Build comprehensive search and filter functionality accessible from any view.

## Layout
```
 Search 
 > from:architect tag:auth since:1h token refresh_        
                                                          
  Saved: [auth-discussion] [high-priority] [today]        
                                                          
  12 results (searched 342 messages in 8 topics)          
                                                          
   [task] architect (15:30)  2 matches                 
    implement JWT auth...token refresh with sliding window 
    matching context 
                                                          
    [task] coder-1 (15:31)  1 match                     
    ...should refresh tokens be single-use or reusable?   
                                                          
    [@coder-1] architect (15:34)  1 match               
    Single-use. Each refresh mints a new refresh token... 
                                                          
    [build] architect (15:32)  0 matches (context)      
    run full test suite (adjacent to matching thread)      
                                                          

 Enter: open thread  Tab: next match  s: save search  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Search input bar:
  - Full-width text input at the top of the view
  - Real-time search-as-you-type with debounce (200ms after last keystroke)
  - Query syntax (all optional, combinable):
    - Free text: matches against message body (case-insensitive)
    - `from:<agent>`  filter by sender (supports glob: `from:coder-*`)
    - `to:<topic|@agent>`  filter by target
    - `priority:<high|normal|low>`  filter by priority
    - `tag:<tag>`  filter by tag (multiple tag: filters ANDed)
    - `since:<duration>`  messages newer than (1h, 30m, 2d, 1w)
    - `until:<duration>`  messages older than
    - `has:reply`  only messages that have been replied to
    - `has:bookmark`  only bookmarked messages
    - `is:unread`  only unread messages
    - `in:<topic>`  scope to specific topic
  - Syntax highlighting in the input: keywords in blue, values in green, free text in white
  - Tab completion for agent names, topic names, and filter keywords
- Search results:
  - Grouped by topic, sorted by relevance (match count) then recency
  - Each result shows: topic tag, agent (colored), timestamp, match count
  - Matching text highlighted with bold/underline in the message body
  - Context: show 1 message before and after each match for context
  - Result count and search performance stats in header ("12 results in 342 messages")
- Result navigation:
  - j/k to move between results
  - Tab/Shift+Tab to jump between highlighted matches
  - Enter on a result  push to Thread View, scrolled to that message
  - `o` to open the message in context (show surrounding thread)
- Saved searches:
  - Press `s` to save current search with a name
  - Saved searches shown as pills below the search bar
  - Click/Enter on a pill to load that search
  - `x` on a pill to delete it
  - Saved in tui-state.json
- Search index (optimization for large message stores):
  - Build an in-memory inverted index on first search
  - Index: word  set of message IDs
  - Rebuild index on new messages (incremental: only index new messages)
  - Falls back to linear scan if index not ready

## Technical Notes
- Search runs against the data provider's Search() method
- For the inverted index: tokenize message bodies by splitting on whitespace/punctuation
- Case-insensitive matching: lowercase all tokens in the index
- Glob matching for from:/to: filters: use filepath.Match semantics
- Duration parsing: support h (hours), m (minutes), d (days), w (weeks)
- Performance: search should feel instant for <1000 messages, <500ms for 10,000+
- Debounce search-as-you-type to avoid excessive re-renders

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Notifications panel and rules engine
tasks.body:
Build a notification system with configurable rules for alerting on important messages.

## Layout  Notifications Panel
```
 Notifications  3 unread 
                                                          
   15:34 HIGH  architect  @coder-1                    
    Single-use refresh tokens...                          
                                                          
   15:32 RULE "auth-watch"  architect  task           
    implement JWT auth...                                 
                                                          
   15:20 RULE "build-alerts"  tester  build           
    test suite failed: 3 failures in auth/...             
                                                          
   14:55 HIGH  deployer  deploy                       
    production deployment starting...                     
                                                          

  RULES (4 active)                                        
   "high-priority"  priority:high  bell + highlight   
   "auth-watch"  tag:auth  highlight                  
   "build-alerts"  topic:build from:tester  bell      
   "deploy-dm"  to:@deployer  bell (disabled)         
                                                          

 Enter: go to msg  n: new rule  e: edit rule  d: delete  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Notification panel:
  - Accessible via `Ctrl+N` or notification badge on the dashboard
  - Lists messages that matched notification rules, sorted by recency
  - Unread notifications marked with  (read with )
  - Each shows: time, rule that matched (or "HIGH" for priority-based), sender  target, preview
  - Enter on a notification  jump to that message in Thread View
  - `c` to clear all notifications, `x` to dismiss one
  - Badge on dashboard: shows unread notification count (e.g., "[3]" next to the Notifications keybinding)
- Notification rules:
  - Each rule has:
    - Name: user-defined label
    - Conditions (all must match):
      - topic: glob pattern for topic name
      - from: glob pattern for sender agent
      - to: glob pattern for target
      - priority: minimum priority (high, normal, low)
      - tags: required tags (any of the listed tags must be present)
      - text: regex pattern to match in message body
    - Actions:
      - highlight: bold the message in all views
      - bell: terminal bell (BEL character)
      - flash: briefly invert header bar colors
      - badge: increment notification badge on dashboard
    - Enabled: boolean toggle
  - Default rules (created on first run):
    - "high-priority": matches priority:high, actions: bell + highlight + badge
    - "direct-messages": matches messages sent to the TUI's own agent, actions: badge + highlight
- Rule editor:
  - Press `n` for new rule, `e` to edit selected rule
  - Form with fields for each condition and action
  - Toggle conditions on/off (not all are required)
  - Test button: "Run this rule against the last 100 messages" to preview matches
- Notification processing:
  - On each new message (from Subscribe()), evaluate all enabled rules
  - If any rule matches, trigger its actions
  - Store matched notifications in memory (last 200) and in tui-state.json (last 50)
- Global notification indicator:
  - In ALL views, the footer bar shows notification count if >0
  - Format: " 3" or "[N:3]" in the status bar
  - Clicking/pressing the notification keybinding opens the panel

## Technical Notes
- Rule evaluation: for each message, iterate rules and check conditions
  - Short-circuit: if any condition fails, skip to next rule
  - Glob matching: use filepath.Match for topic/from/to patterns
  - Text matching: compile regex once on rule create, apply on each message
- Performance: rule evaluation must be <1ms per message (evaluate synchronously in Subscribe handler)
- Terminal bell: write '\a' to stdout (tea.Println or raw write)
- Flash effect: set a timer that inverts header style for 500ms, then reverts
- Store notification rules in tui-state.json NotifyRules field
- Notification deduplication: don't re-notify for messages already in the notification list

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Agent Roster view

Build the Agent Roster  a detailed view of all known agents with activity history.

 Agents  4 known

  15:32  build: run full test suite                     
  15:30  task: implement JWT auth for the...            

 Enter: messages  s: sort  / filter  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Agent list (top pane):
  - Columns: name (colored), status message, host, last seen (relative)
  - Presence indicators:  online (<1m),  recent (<10m),  stale (>10m),  offline (>1h)
  - Sort options (cycle with `s`): name, last seen, message count, host
  - Filter by typing (fuzzy match on name/status/host)
- Agent detail (bottom pane, shows for selected agent):
  - Full agent record: name, host, first_seen, last_seen, status
  - Activity sparkline: message frequency over the last N hours using braille/block characters
    - Each column = 15 min bucket, height = message count in that bucket
    - Shows the last 4 hours by default, adjustable with `[` and `]` keys
  - Topic participation: list of topics this agent has sent messages to, with count
  - Recent messages: last 10 messages from this agent across all topics
    - Show: timestamp, target (topic or @agent), first line of body
    - Enter on a message  jump to that message in Thread View
- Agent unified history (Enter on an agent):
  - Push to a new view showing ALL messages from this agent across all topics/DMs
  - Chronological order, each message prefixed with its topic/DM target
  - Same message rendering as Thread View but flat
- Uptime timeline bar:
  - Horizontal bar showing the last 24 hours
  - Green segments where agent was active (sent messages)
  - Grey/empty segments where agent was silent
  - Granularity: 30-minute blocks

## Technical Notes
- Agent data comes from .fmail/agents/*.json (via data provider)
- Message history requires scanning all topics  cache aggressively
- Activity sparkline: use rune characters  for 8 levels of height
- Presence thresholds should be configurable in Preferences
- Auto-refresh agent list every 5s or on new message events

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Compose overlay and quick-send bar
tasks.body:
Build the foundational compose UI components: the modal overlay for composing messages and the quick-send command bar. This is the plumbing that the full Human Operator Console (forge-p2m) builds on.

## Layout  Compose Overlay
```
 Compose 
                                                          
  To: task_______        (Tab to autocomplete)            
  Priority: [normal ]                                    
  Tags: auth, urgent_    (comma-separated)                
  Reply to: 20260209-153000-0001  (auto-filled)          
                                                          
   
   Here's the implementation plan for JWT auth:         
                                                        
   1. RS256 signing with rotating keys                  
   2. 15-minute access token expiry                     
   3. Single-use refresh tokens                         
                                                        
   I'll start with the token service.                   
   
                                                          
  [Ctrl+Enter: Send]  [Esc: Cancel]  [Tab: Next field]   

```

## Deliverables
- Compose overlay (modal):
  - Triggered by: `n` (new message), `r` (reply to selected message)
  - Semi-transparent overlay on top of current view
  - Fields:
    - To: text input with tab-completion for agent names (@agent) and topic names
      - Autocomplete dropdown showing matching agents/topics as user types
      - Pre-filled when replying (to = sender of selected message) or when in a topic view
    - Priority: dropdown selector (low / normal / high), default normal
    - Tags: comma-separated text input with tab-completion for existing tags
    - Reply to: auto-filled when using `r`, shows the parent message ID + preview
    - Body: multi-line text area (main input)
  - Tab cycles between fields, Enter in single-line fields moves to next field
  - Ctrl+Enter: send the message
  - Esc: cancel (with confirmation if body is non-empty: "Discard draft?")
- Message sending:
  - Sends via the data provider (which uses forged socket if available, file store otherwise)
  - Show sending indicator ("Sending...") with spinner
  - On success: close overlay, show brief "Sent " notification, message appears in feed
  - On error: show error message in the overlay, keep draft intact for retry
  - Set FMAIL_AGENT identity from CLI flag or auto-detect
- Reply mode:
  - `r` on a selected message  opens compose with:
    - To: pre-filled with the topic (or @sender for DMs)
    - Reply to: set to the selected message's ID
    - Body: empty, but header shows "Replying to: <first line of parent message>"
  - `R` (shift+r)  reply to sender directly (DM) regardless of where the original was posted
- Quick send bar:
  - From any view, press `:` to open a one-line quick send bar at the bottom of the screen
  - Syntax: `:<target> <message>` (e.g., `:task implement JWT auth`)
  - Press Enter to send immediately
  - Tab completion for target names in the quick send bar
  - No priority/tag/reply-to options (uses defaults)
  - Great for fast, informal messages
  - History: / to cycle through previous quick-sends
- Draft persistence:
  - If user navigates away from compose (Esc), offer to save draft
  - Drafts stored in tui-state.json
  - On next compose, offer to restore last draft if target matches

## Technical Notes
- Multi-line text input: use charmbracelet/bubbles textarea component
- Tab completion: build a trie or sorted list of known agents/topics, filter on prefix
- Autocomplete dropdown: rendered as a small list below the input, navigate with /
- Send via fmail store: write JSON message file to .fmail/topics/<topic>/ or .fmail/dm/<agent>/
  - Or send via forged socket: {"cmd":"send","to":"<target>","body":"<msg>","agent":"<self>"}
- Identity: the TUI needs to know "who am I"  set via --agent flag or FMAIL_AGENT env var
  - If not set, register as "tui-<pid>" or prompt user on first send
- Ctrl+Enter detection: tea.KeyMsg with ctrl+enter (may need platform-specific handling)

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Topic Browser view
tasks.body:
Build the Topic Browser  a navigable list of all topics with preview pane.

## Layout
```
 Topics 
 Filter: _________                                        
                                                          
  TOPIC         MSGS  LAST ACTIVE   AGENTS               
  task          47   2m ago        architect, coder-1    
   build         23   5m ago        coder-1, tester       
   editing        8   1h ago        coder-1               
   deploy         3   3h ago        deployer              
   review        15   15m ago       reviewer, architect   
    alerts       2   1d ago        monitor               

  Preview: task                                          
                                                         
  15:34 architect        15:33 coder-1                   
  Use sliding window     need clarification on           
  for token refresh.     token refresh flow              
  Reply in 30min.                                        
                         15:31 coder-1                   
  15:32 architect        on it, ETA 30min                
  run full test suite                                    

 Enter: open   star  d: DMs   navigate  / filter  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Topic list (top/left pane):
  - Sortable columns: topic name, message count, last active, participants
  - Default sort: last active (most recent first)
  - Cycle sort with `s` key (name  count  activity  participants)
  - Starred/pinned topics always at top (persisted in tui-state.json)
  - Star/unstar with `` or `*` key
  - Color-coded activity heat: hot (red/orange for active), warm (yellow), cold (grey for idle)
  - Activity thresholds configurable but defaults: hot=<5m, warm=<1h, cold=>1h
  - Fuzzy filter: typing in the filter box narrows the list instantly
  - Show total unread count per topic (from ReadMarkers in tui-state)
  - Unread topics shown in bold
- Preview pane (bottom/right):
  - Shows last N messages (default 10) from the selected topic
  - Messages rendered with agent colors and timestamps
  - Preview updates as cursor moves through topic list
  - Scrollable within the preview pane
- Navigation:
  - Enter on a topic  push to Thread View for that topic
  - `d`  switch to DM browser (similar layout but for direct messages)
  - `n`  compose new message to this topic
  - Esc  back to dashboard
- DM Browser (toggled with `d`):
  - Same layout but shows DM conversations instead of topics
  - Grouped by conversation partner
  - Show unread count per conversation
  - Enter  open DM thread

## Technical Notes
- Use the data provider's Topics() method, refresh on a timer (2s) or on new message events
- Fuzzy filtering: simple substring match is fine for V1, upgrade to fuzzy scoring later
- Preview pane reads messages lazily  only fetch when topic is highlighted
- Cache preview messages to avoid re-reading when navigating back
- Topic metadata (message count, participants) computed from message scan or cached

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Local state persistence (read markers, bookmarks, settings)
tasks.body:
Implement local TUI state that persists across sessions, stored in .fmail/tui-state.json.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/state/state.go`  TUIState struct and persistence:
  ```go
  type TUIState struct {
      ReadMarkers   map[string]string          // topic/dm -> last-read message ID
      Bookmarks     []Bookmark                  // saved message references
      Annotations   map[string]string           // message ID -> user annotation text
      StarredTopics []string                    // pinned/starred topic names
      SavedSearches []SavedSearch               // named search presets
      Preferences   Preferences                 // UI preferences
      NotifyRules   []NotificationRule          // notification configuration
      LastView      string                      // last active view (for session restore)
      LastTopic     string                      // last viewed topic
  }
  
  type Bookmark struct {
      MessageID string
      Topic     string    // topic name or "@agent" for DMs
      Note      string    // optional user note
      CreatedAt time.Time
  }
  
  type SavedSearch struct {
      Name   string
      Query  SearchQuery
  }
  
  type Preferences struct {
      DefaultLayout string   // "single", "split", "dashboard", "zen"
      LiveTailAuto  bool     // auto-scroll in live tail mode
      RelativeTime  bool     // show "2m ago" vs full timestamp
      SoundAlerts   bool     // terminal bell on notifications
  }
  
  type NotificationRule struct {
      Name     string
      Topic    string   // topic filter (glob pattern)
      From     string   // agent filter (glob pattern)
      Priority string   // min priority (high, normal, low)
      Tags     []string // required tags
      Enabled  bool
  }
  ```
- Load on startup, save on change (debounced writes, max 1 write/sec)
- File locking for concurrent access (in case multiple TUI instances)
- Migration support: version field in JSON, upgrade logic for schema changes
- Unread count computation: compare ReadMarkers against actual message IDs

## Technical Notes
- Store at .fmail/tui-state.json (not in topics/ or dm/ to avoid polluting message dirs)
- Use atomic write (write to .tmp, rename) to avoid corruption
- ReadMarkers use the last-read message ID  since IDs are sortable, any message with ID > marker is unread
- Keep file small: prune bookmarks older than 30 days on save, limit to 500 bookmarks
- This is purely local state  never synced via forged or across hosts

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Conversation Thread view
tasks.body:
Build the Thread View  the primary view for reading messages within a topic or DM conversation.

## Layout
```
 task  47 messages 
                                                          
   architect (15:30)  
   implement JWT auth for the user service.             
   Requirements: RS256 signing, 15min expiry,           
   refresh tokens with sliding window.                  
   Priority: high  Tags: [auth] [urgent]                
  
     coder-1 (15:31)  
     on it, ETA 30min. Quick question  should          
     refresh tokens be single-use or reusable?          
    
       architect (15:34)  
         Single-use. Each refresh mints a new           
         refresh token alongside the access token.      
        
                                                          
   tester (15:45)  
   Integration test suite is ready. Run with:           
   `go test ./auth/... -tags=integration`               
  
                                                          

 r reply  b bookmark  / search  j/k scroll  g/G top/bot  Esc back
```

## Deliverables
- Threaded message display:
  - Uses the thread reconstruction engine to group messages into threads
  - Thread roots displayed at base indentation
  - Replies indented with tree connectors (, , )
  - Max visible indent depth: 6 levels (deeper threads flatten with a "..." indicator)
  - Each message card shows:
    - Header: agent name (in their color) + timestamp (relative by default, full on focus)
    - Body: full message text with word wrapping
    - Footer (if applicable): priority badge, tag pills, reply-to indicator
    - Unread indicator: bold left border or dot for messages newer than ReadMarker
  - Empty lines between thread groups for visual separation
- Message selection:
  - j/k or / to move between messages
  - Selected message highlighted with accent border
  - Enter on a message  expand/collapse its children (if threaded)
  - Full message details on focus (show full timestamp, message ID, host)
- Message body rendering:
  - Wrap to pane width
  - Preserve code blocks (``` fenced) with syntax-highlighted background
  - Inline code (`backtick`) with distinct background
  - Truncate extremely long messages (>50 lines) with "... [show more]"  Enter to expand
- Scroll behavior:
  - j/k message-by-message, Ctrl+D/Ctrl+U half-page, g/G top/bottom
  - Scroll position remembered when navigating away and back
  - "New messages" indicator at bottom when scrolled up and new messages arrive
  - Jump to newest with G or clicking the indicator
- Flat mode toggle:
  - Press `f` to toggle between threaded and flat (chronological) view
  - Flat view shows all messages in time order without indentation
  - Useful when threads are sparse or reply_to is rarely used
- Header bar: topic name + message count + participant count
- Mark-as-read: automatically advance ReadMarker as user scrolls through messages

## Technical Notes
- Thread view is the most important view  invest heavily in rendering quality
- Use the threading.FlattenThread() to get display order
- Message cards should be lipgloss-styled boxes with agent-colored left border
- For performance, virtualize the list  only render visible messages + buffer
  (Bubbletea viewport or custom scroll implementation)
- Re-render only on: new message, scroll, resize, or selection change
- If the topic has >1000 messages, paginate (load 100 at a time, fetch more on scroll-up)

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Live Dashboard view (home screen)
tasks.body:
Build the main dashboard view  the home screen users see when launching the TUI.

## Layout (responsive to terminal width)

   coder-1    "JWT auth"        implement JWT auth

                               15:32 architect  build

   task       12 msgs/5m     15:33 coder-1  @arch    
   build      3 msgs/5m       need clarification on   
   editing    idle             token refresh flow      
   deploy     idle           15:34 architect  @coder  
                                 use sliding window...   
                                                         

 [T]opics [A]gents [/]Search [L]ive tail  [?]Help  q Quit
```

## Deliverables
- Left panel  Agent roster (compact):
  - Show all agents sorted by last_seen (most recent first)
  - Presence indicators:  online (<1m),  recent (<10m),  stale (>10m)
  - Status message truncated to fit column width
  - Agent name in their assigned color
  - Click/Enter to jump to Agent Detail view
- Left panel  Topic summary (below agents):
  - List topics sorted by recent activity
  - Activity bar: visual indicator of messages in last 5 minutes (miniature bar chart using block chars )
  - Show message count in time window
  - Click/Enter to jump to Topic view
- Right panel  Live message feed:
  - Real-time stream of ALL messages across all topics and DMs
  - Each message: timestamp, sender (colored)  target, first line of body

- Buffer up to 500 messages in the feed (drop oldest when full)

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Thread reconstruction engine (reply_to chain building)
tasks.body:
Build a thread reconstruction engine that assembles flat messages into threaded conversations using the reply_to field.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/threading/threading.go`:
  ```go
  type Thread struct {
      Root     *fmail.Message   // first message (or the one with no reply_to in the chain)
      Messages []*ThreadNode    // all messages in chronological order
      Depth    int              // max nesting depth
      Agents   []string         // unique participating agents
      LastActivity time.Time    // most recent message timestamp
  }
  
  type ThreadNode struct {
      Message  *fmail.Message
      Parent   *ThreadNode      // nil if root
      Children []*ThreadNode    // replies to this message
      Depth    int              // nesting level (0 = root)
  }
  
  // BuildThreads takes a flat list of messages and returns threaded conversations
  func BuildThreads(messages []fmail.Message) []*Thread
  
  // BuildThread reconstructs a single thread from a root message ID
  func BuildThread(messages []fmail.Message, rootID string) *Thread
  
  // FlattenThread returns messages in display order (depth-first, chronological siblings)
  func FlattenThread(thread *Thread) []*ThreadNode
  ```
- Thread building algorithm:
  1. Index all messages by ID in a map
  2. For each message with reply_to, link to parent
  3. Messages with no reply_to (or reply_to not found) become thread roots
  4. Sort roots by earliest message timestamp
  5. Sort children within each parent by timestamp
  6. Handle orphaned replies gracefully (reply_to points to unknown ID  treat as new root)
  7. Handle cross-topic replies (reply_to from a different topic  show with a "from topic X" indicator)
- Thread summary generation: first line of root message + participant count + message count + last activity

## Technical Notes
- Many messages will have no reply_to (standalone messages)  each becomes a single-message thread
- Thread depth should be capped at a display limit (e.g., 10 levels) to prevent pathological nesting
- This is a pure data transformation  no I/O, no state, fully testable
- Write comprehensive tests with edge cases: circular reply_to, self-reply, missing parent, deep chains
- Performance target: reconstruct threads for 10,000 messages in <100ms

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Message data layer and store abstraction
tasks.body:
Build the data layer that the TUI uses to read messages, agents, and topics from both the fmail file store and the forged daemon.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/data/provider.go`  interface abstracting message access:
  ```go
  type MessageProvider interface {
      // List topics with metadata (message count, last activity, participants)
      Topics() ([]TopicInfo, error)
      // List messages in a topic, with optional filters (since, from, priority, tags)
      Messages(topic string, opts MessageFilter) ([]fmail.Message, error)
      // List DM conversations for a given agent
      DMConversations(agent string) ([]DMConversation, error)
      // List DMs with a specific agent
      DMs(agent string, opts MessageFilter) ([]fmail.Message, error)
      // List all known agents
      Agents() ([]fmail.AgentRecord, error)
      // Search across all messages
      Search(query SearchQuery) ([]SearchResult, error)
      // Subscribe to new messages (returns a channel)
      Subscribe(filter SubscriptionFilter) (<-chan fmail.Message, func())
  }
  ```
- `FileProvider`  implementation backed by .fmail/ directory reads
  - Scans topics/ and dm/ directories
  - Parses JSON message files
  - Caches results with TTL (configurable, default 500ms)
  - File-based polling for Subscribe() at configurable interval
- `ForgedProvider`  implementation backed by forged socket connection
  - Connects via Unix socket or TCP
  - Uses the line-delimited JSON protocol (cmd: watch, send, etc.)
  - Real-time Subscribe() via watch stream
  - Falls back to FileProvider if connection lost
- `HybridProvider`  wraps both, prefers forged for live data, file store for historical queries
  - Auto-detects forged availability (check for .fmail/forged.sock)
  - Transparent fallback with reconnect attempts
- TopicInfo struct: Name, MessageCount, LastActivity time.Time, Participants []string, LastMessage *fmail.Message
- DMConversation struct: Agent string, MessageCount int, LastActivity time.Time, UnreadCount int
- SearchQuery struct: Text string, From string, To string, Priority string, Tags []string, Since/Until time.Time
- SearchResult struct: Message fmail.Message, Topic string, MatchOffset int, MatchLength int

## Technical Notes
- Message IDs are sortable (YYYYMMDD-HHMMSS-NNNN)  use this for efficient range queries
- For file-based scanning, use os.ReadDir and sort by filename (=chronological order)
- Keep an in-memory message cache with LRU eviction to avoid re-reading files
- The Subscribe channel should deliver messages in order, buffering if consumer is slow
- Forged protocol: send {"cmd":"watch","topic":"*","agent":"tui-viewer"} for all-topics stream

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Bubbletea app scaffold and entry point
tasks.body:
Create the foundational Bubbletea application scaffold for the fmail TUI.

## Deliverables
- New package: `internal/fmailtui/` with app.go as the main model
- `cmd/fmail-tui/main.go` entry point (or integrate as `fmail tui` subcommand)
- Bubbletea Model/Init/Update/View lifecycle wired up

## Technical Notes
- Follow the pattern in internal/tui/app.go but keep it much leaner
- Use a viewStack []viewID for breadcrumb-style navigation (push on enter, pop on Esc/backspace)
- Each view is a sub-model implementing its own Update/View
- Global keybindings handled before delegating to active view
- The model should hold references to shared state: fmail.Store, forgedClient (nullable), theme/styles, terminal dimensions

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Styling system and agent color assignment
tasks.body:
Build the theming/styling layer for the fmail TUI, including deterministic per-agent color assignment.

## Deliverables
- `internal/fmailtui/styles/theme.go`  Theme struct with all styled components:
  - Base colors: background, foreground, muted, accent, border
  - Message colors: own-message, other-message, system-message
  - Priority colors: high (red/bold), normal (default), low (dim)
  - Status colors: online (green), recent (yellow), stale (dim/grey)
  - UI chrome: header, footer, breadcrumb, selected-item, scrollbar
  - Borders: active-pane, inactive-pane, divider
- `styles/palette_default.go` and `styles/palette_high_contrast.go`  two theme palettes
- `styles/agent_colors.go`  deterministic agent color assignment:
  - Hash agent name to a color from a curated palette of 12-16 distinguishable terminal colors
  - Same agent always gets the same color across all views
  - Colors should be ANSI 256-compatible for wide terminal support
  - Provide both foreground and background variants
  - Cache computed colors in a map[string]lipgloss.Style
- `styles/message.go`  pre-built lipgloss styles for message rendering:
  - Message header (agent name in their color + timestamp)
  - Message body (with proper wrapping)
  - Reply indicator (indented with vertical bar)
  - Priority badge ([HIGH], [LOW])
  - Tag pills ([tag1] [tag2])
  - Unread indicator (bold/dot)
- `styles/layout.go`  layout helpers:
  - Responsive column widths based on terminal width
  - Consistent padding/margin constants
  - Panel border styles (focused vs unfocused)

## Technical Notes
- Use lipgloss from charmbracelet (already a dependency)
- Agent color hash: fnv32a(agentName) % len(colorPalette)  simple and deterministic
- Color palette should avoid red (reserved for high priority) and green (reserved for online status)
- Ensure all text has sufficient contrast in both default and high-contrast themes
- Follow existing patterns in internal/tui/styles/ but keep independent

tasks.title: fmail TUI: Human Operator Console  command center for directing agents
tasks.body:
Build a dedicated "Operator Console" view designed specifically for a human user sitting at the TUI, directing and interacting with a swarm of agents. This goes far beyond basic compose  it's the command center for a human orchestrating AI agents.

## Layout  Operator Console
```
 Operator Console  you: tormod 
                                                          
  CONVERSATION with architect  
    architect (15:30)                                  
   Here's my analysis of the auth module. I found 3     
   issues: 1) Token expiry not enforced 2) Missing      
   refresh rotation 3) No rate limiting on login.       
                                                        
    you (15:32)                                        
   Good catches. Fix #1 and #2 now, create a ticket     
   for #3. Use single-use refresh tokens.               
                                                        
    architect (15:33)                                  
   On it. I'll also loop in coder-1 for the refresh     
   token implementation.                                
                                                        
  
   QUICK ACTIONS                                        
   [1] Broadcast to all  [2] @architect  [3] @coder-1  
   [4]  task topic      [5]  build topic              
  
                                                        
   > Fix the token rotation and let me know when the_   
                                                        
   To: @architect  Priority: normal  Ctrl+Enter: Send 
  
                                                          
  AGENT STATUS  
   architect  "fixing token expiry"         30s ago    
   coder-1    "implementing refresh flow"   1m ago     
   tester     "waiting for build"           5m ago     

 1-5: quick target  Tab: switch conversation  Esc: back
```

## Deliverables

### Chat-Style Conversation View
- Shows YOUR conversation history with the currently selected agent/topic
- Messages displayed in a familiar chat-bubble style:
  - Your messages: right-aligned or distinct "you" color/style, clearly distinguished
  - Agent messages: left-aligned with agent color
  - Timestamps between message groups (not on every message)
  - "Typing..." or "working..." indicator based on agent status updates
- Conversation list sidebar (left, collapsible):
  - All agents and topics you've interacted with, sorted by recency
  - Unread badges per conversation
  - Tab or number keys to switch between conversations
  - New conversation: `n` to start composing to a new target
- Auto-follow: conversation auto-scrolls when new messages arrive from the focused agent
- Context display: when an agent references a topic message in a DM, show an inline preview of that message

### Compose Area (Always Visible)
- Persistent compose area at the bottom of the console  NOT a modal overlay
- Always visible, always ready for input (like a real chat app)
- Multi-line text area with word wrap
- Current target shown in the compose footer: "To: @architect" with easy switching
- Target switching:
  - Number keys (1-9) for quick-access targets (most recent conversations)
  - Tab-completion in a "To:" prefix if you want to change target inline
  - `/dm architect` to switch to a specific agent
  - `/topic task` to switch to a specific topic
- Slash commands in the compose area:
  - `/broadcast <msg>`  send to all active agents
  - `/dm <agent> <msg>`  quick DM without switching context
  - `/topic <name> <msg>`  post to a topic without switching
  - `/status`  show all agents and their current status
  - `/assign <agent> <task>`  send a task assignment (high priority, tagged "assignment")
  - `/ask <agent> <question>`  send a question (tagged "question", expects reply)
  - `/approve <msg-id>`  reply with approval (tagged "approved")
  - `/reject <msg-id> <reason>`  reply with rejection (tagged "rejected")
  - `/priority high|normal|low`  set priority for next message
  - `/tag <tags...>`  set tags for next message
- Command palette: `Ctrl+P` shows all available slash commands with descriptions
- Send with Enter (single line) or Ctrl+Enter (multi-line mode toggle with Ctrl+M)

### Quick Actions Bar
- Horizontal bar above the compose area with numbered quick-access targets
- Shows the 5-9 most relevant targets:
  - Agents who recently messaged you (highest priority)
  - Topics with recent activity
  - Agents you recently messaged
- Number keys 1-9 to instantly switch compose target
- Visual indicator showing which target is currently active
- Customizable: pin favorite targets to specific number slots (persisted)

### Agent Status Ticker
- Compact agent status bar below or beside the conversation
- Shows all known agents with: presence dot, name, status message, last activity
- Live-updating as agents send status updates
- Click/select an agent to start a conversation with them
- Visual grouping: "active" agents (online) at top, "idle" at bottom

### Broadcast & Multi-Send
- Broadcast mode: send a message to ALL active agents simultaneously
  - Trigger with `/broadcast` or a dedicated keybinding (Ctrl+A for "all")
  - Confirmation prompt: "Send to 6 agents? [y/N]"
  - Each agent gets an individual DM (not a topic post)
  - Or post to a configurable "announcements" topic
- Multi-select: hold Ctrl and click/select multiple agents, compose one message sent to all
- Group compose: create ad-hoc groups (e.g., "frontend team" = coder-1, coder-2, designer)
  - `/group create frontend coder-1 coder-2 designer`
  - `/group frontend <msg>` to message the whole group

### Feedback & Approval Workflow
- When an agent sends a message tagged "question" or "needs-approval":
  - Message highlighted with a distinct border/badge
  - Inline action buttons: [Approve] [Reject] [Reply]
  - `y` to approve (sends reply tagged "approved")
  - `x` to reject (opens compose for rejection reason)
  - These appear in the notification panel AND in the conversation
- Feedback templates:
  - Quick reactions: `:thumbsup:`, `:thumbsdown:`, `:eyes:`  sent as short reply messages
  - Template library: pre-written responses for common patterns
    - "Looks good, proceed" / "Hold off, let me review" / "Needs changes: ..."
  - Configurable templates in tui-state.json
- Priority escalation: when you send a high-priority message, it gets a visual "urgent" treatment in the agent's view

### Notification Integration
- Unread message count per conversation shown in sidebar
- Desktop notification (terminal bell) when an agent DMs you
- Flash/highlight when an agent mentions your name in a topic
- "Waiting for reply" indicators: if you asked a question >5m ago with no response, show a subtle reminder

### Identity & Presence
- Your identity prominently shown: "you: tormod" in the header
- Set via `--agent` flag, `FMAIL_AGENT` env, or prompted on first launch
- Your status: set with `/mystatus working on auth review`  visible to all agents
- Auto-presence: TUI automatically registers you as an active agent while open
  - Updates last_seen on every interaction
  - Clears presence on exit (or marks as "offline")

## Technical Notes
- The operator console is a new view (not a replacement for the compose overlay)
- It can be the DEFAULT view when launched with `fmail tui --operator` or `-o` flag
- Conversation history: aggregated from DMs sent/received + topic messages where the user participated
- For "chat style" rendering: track which messages are "mine" vs "theirs" based on FMAIL_AGENT identity
- Quick action targets: computed from recent message history, refreshed on new messages
- Slash command parser: split on first space, match command prefix, pass rest as args
- Group storage: tui-state.json under a "groups" key: map[string][]string
- Enter vs Ctrl+Enter: configurable in preferences, default is Enter=send for single-line
- Auto-presence: tea.Tick every 30s to touch the agent registry file with updated last_seen
- Broadcast: iterate over Agents() from data provider, send to each with @agent targeting

tasks.title: TUI: Implement destructive confirmation flows (S/K/D)
tasks.body:
Implement explicit destructive confirmation behavior from PRD.

Scope:
- Confirmation dialog required for S, K, D using [y/N] default No.
- q/esc cancel confirmation and return to Main mode.
- Exact confirmation copy:
  - S: Stop loop <id> after current iteration? [y/N]
  - K: Kill loop <id> immediately? [y/N]
  - D stopped: Delete loop record <id>? [y/N]
  - D running: Loop is still running. Force delete record <id>? [y/N]
- For D: detect loop running/non-stopped state and branch to force-delete prompt.

Done when:
- destructive actions cannot run without explicit confirmation and prompt text matches PRD.
